Award.AwardTitle: CAP: Building a Cyberlearning Research Program - An Early Career Symposium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Annual Meeting of the Association for Education Communications and Technology (AECT) provides a forum for interchange of ideas around designing technological support for learning and training. Its Early Career Symposia provide an avenue for early career scholars to receive mentoring from established researchers.

This project supports travel for advanced graduate students and new faculty from U.S. universities to attend the Annual Meeting and Early Career Symposium. Sessions during the Symposium are designed to help collaborators imagine forward-looking and viable technology-oriented research agendas, identify the types of collaborators who complement their strengths, and identify the funding agencies and programs that might support their work. An important goal of the Symposium is to add to the community of researchers interested in ways that technology can transform teaching and learning.

This activity supports the mission of NSF to train more advanced professionals in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics education. This conference is one among many that researchers in the cyberlearning community regularly attend. Mentors come from the AECT community as well as from the learning sciences community. The plan for this year's workshop is informed by feedback from attendees at previous AECT Early Career Symposia.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Early Career Symposium offered an avenue for early-career scholars (graduate students and faculty members) to receive mentoring from established researchers who conduct research and development in the next generation of learning technologies. Synergistic collaborations are fundamental to exploring the feasibility of technological innovations, investigating issues that would not be able to be researched in any other way, and extending promising innovations to a multitude of learners. As a result, opportunities to connect, learn and explore are critical for the advancement of Cyberlearning.  

 

The Symposium took place on November 4 to 5, 2015 in Jacksonville, Florida and was part of the Association for Education Communications and Technology (AECT) annual convention program. Four mentors worked with eight graduate students and eight early-career faculty. Each of these mentors was a faculty member who has a strong record of scholarship, successful grant activity and a demonstrated commitment to innovation. In addition, a series of panel discussions were organized around themes such as Success in Higher Education, Writing for Publication & Crafting a Research Agenda, and The Professor as Innovator/ Entrepreneur. Panelists consisted on seven highly respected leaders in Educational Technology and the Learning Sciences. On the last day of the Symposium, participants were able to interact with NSF Program Officer and enjoy a session on grant writing and submission targeted to NSF potential applicants.  

 

In terms of Intellectual Merit, the Symposium brought scholars together and supported conversations across all stages of career growth. Two questionnaires were used to collect evaluative data on the Early Career Symposium. The first one was used immediately at the end of the annual convention and the second was administered 10 months after the Symposium.

 

Ten months after the Symposium, participants reported its success in a variety of ways. The Symposium was instrumental for them in:

- initiating the development of collaborations for seeking NSF funding

- launching interdisciplinary research in Cyberlearning

- continuing the mentoring/dialogue between mentees and mentors

- encouraging the submission of manuscripts for publication

One of the participants wrote: “The symposium gave me fantastic ideas for collaboration with me peers. I am seeking people from other areas in the College of Education to find partnerships and collaborative research, by finding common interests.”

 

In terms of boarder impact the Broader Impacts, the Symposium brought together graduate students and early-career faculty from different higher education institutions (Mississippi State University, Indiana University, University of Georgia, University of Virginia, University of Idaho, University of North Texas, University of Missouri, Virginia Tech and University of West Georgia). Eleven participants were female and five were male. Participants also represented different ethnicities and nationalities. Concurrently, the mentors offered a variety of approaches to scholarship and intellectual perspectives. They came from Department of Educational Psychology and Learning Systems at Florida State University, Innovative Learning and Technology from Royal Roads University, Teaching, Literacy and Leadership Department at Hofstra University and School of Computing, and Informatics and Decisions Systems Engineering at Arizona State University.
